Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as c363323e7ee9e42817922346b1f1ce6adc872d1b
Please review when you have time. Thx

This seems working good.
I have also tested this for https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097
rebased to see if it still passes with the new clang format

Its not working for below query to get a list of error log which associated with hw-isolation record.

```
busctl call -j xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById ssassas entry /xyz/openbmc_project 1 xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Entry isolated_hw_errorlog 2 xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry org.open_power.Logging.PEL.Entry
```

Changed into `!thisPath.contains(id)` then its working.

I think it helps to get associated endpoints which could be in different hierarchy. is it make sense?

For example,


Get all error log entries which associated with hw-isolation record:
```
busctl call -j xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById ssassas entry /xyz/openbmc_project 1 xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Entry isolated_hw_errorlog 2 xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry org.open_power.Logging.PEL.Entry
{
	"type" : "as",
	"data" : [
		[
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/logging/entry/599",
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/logging/entry/600"
		]
	]
}
```

Get all hw-isolation record which associated with error log:

```
busctl call -j xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById ssassas entry /xyz/openbmc_project 2 xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry org.open_power.Logging.PEL.Entry isolated_hw_entry 1 xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Entry
{
	"type" : "as",
	"data" : [
		[
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/hardware_isolation/entry/1",
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/hardware_isolation/entry/2"
		]
	]
}
```

Get all power supply which associated with chassis:

(Tested this case which in mentioned in the https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-objmgr/+/70699 change commit mssage)

```
busctl call -j xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById ssassas chassis /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory 1 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis powered_by 1 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PowerSupply
{
	"type" : "as",
	"data" : [
		[
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply0",
			"/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply1"
		]
	]
}
```
Ramesh I think you said you just were calling it wrong?

These new methods are designed for the cases when `id` is uniquely specified in the system - https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/522846cf10edf2bee60aa6867594db1efd8cd585/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/ObjectMapper.interface.yaml#L171

In case PEL, many of the leaf names may be duplicated as they are using the incremental seq numbers - e.g. `entry/1`, `entry/2` etc.

To use these new methods, I think those PEL entries may need to be renamed like `entry/hw_1`, etc so that they are uniquely identified from the other types of PEL entries.

The related uniqueness on dbus name is also discussed 
- https://github.com/openbmc/technical-oversight-forum/issues/18
- https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/41468

> Ramesh, I think you mentioned it was just a wrong call?

Matt, it only works with !thisPath.contains(id).

> These new methods are designed for cases where the id is uniquely specified in the system.

Myung,

I understand your point, but the API could be slightly adjusted to support the use cases I mentioned earlier.

There may be associations where the leaf object name is unique and incremented as you said, but per the DBus spec, it cannot be duplicated. To retrieve these associations, we could specify the immediate parent object ID of the leaf object with the `id` parameter, the required interfaces using the `subtreeInterfaces` parameter, and the common object path hierarchy between the associated objects using the `objectPath` parameter. This would provide a list of associated objects.

For example, to get a list of error logs associated with hardware isolation entries:

```
busctl call -j xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById ssassas entry /xyz/openbmc_project 1 xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Entry isolated_hw_errorlog 2 xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry org.open_power.Logging.PEL.Entry
{
    "type" : "as",
    "data" : [
        [
            "/xyz/openbmc_project/logging/entry/599",
            "/xyz/openbmc_project/logging/entry/600"
        ]
    ]
}
```
Here’s a breakdown:

Immediate parent object ID of the hw-isolation entry: `entry`
HW-Isolation entry interfaces: `xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Entry`
Common object path hierarchy: `/xyz/openbmc_project`
Error log association ID: `isolated_hw_errorlog`
Error log entry interfaces: `xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry` and `org.open_power.Logging.PEL.Entry`


The current API handles "Getting all power supplies associated with a particular chassis." However, it won't handle "Getting all power supplies associated with all chassis."

This could be resolved by either adding a `depth` parameter or checking whether the given `id` is contained in the path, rather than simply checking if it ends with `id`. The subtreeInterfaces parameter would filter out the necessary objects and ignore other matching objects like dump entries.

That said, I understand the limitations of this API proposal. We may need to address this separately or propose a new API to support use cases like "Getting all power supplies associated with a particular chassis." So, removing my `-1` score.

It would be ideal to address this now so that we could avoid additional API. If it's not possible, that's fine; we can revisit it in the future.

This new method is mainly to optimize/reduce the number of dbus-calls to do the existing `GetAssociatedSubTreePaths()` which requires the full dbus path. 
Thus to use it, typically a dbus call (e.g. GetSubTreePaths) is needed to find the full dbus path out of `id`.  There are currently many use patterns in bmcweb.

>The current API handles "Getting all power supplies associated with a particular chassis." However, it won't handle "Getting all power supplies associated with all chassis."

Right.  This is for specific given `id` (e.g. a chassis). 
For multiple ids, multiple calls would need be needed (e.g. `id1`, `id2` etc).

The wildcard cases (e.g. all chassises) are not considered here.
(I think such implementation may not be very efficient as a generic method).

So, unless if it can be easily & efficiently done with this API (or some modified ones) and its implementation, it may be better to consider separately in the future when there are more use patterns.
(I'll mark this conversation as Resolved.  If there are some suggestions, please make another comment)
it would be nice to have comments somewhere describing what this function does.

I add a short comment above the function like
>// This function works like getSubTreePaths() but only matching id with
// the leaf-name instead of full path.

I'm also intending to add doc to https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/architecture/object-mapper.md
it's a bit unsettling to have the interfaces vector sorted as a side effect of this call, but I suppose it's just passed through from the dbus code.

The function `std::set_intersection()` requires the sorted inputs - https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/set_intersection.

The caller may potentially specify the unsorted list of interfaces, and thus it needs to be sorted for the coming `std::set_intersection()` call.
getSubTreePathsById isn't returning a reference, so there's no need for this to be a reference.  Return value optimization will elide the copy.

This part is modeled after the existing code - https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-objmgr/blob/9052ebd36b0e4a016f769983b774dff49a3ea423/src/handler.cpp#L326C1-L327C67

I think - using `const type& var = function()` still has a potential optimization benefit - which compiler may avoid the move of the return var from function to this scope.

So, I'd like to leave this as is.
@Patrick what are your thoughts on this?

I don't know how this even compiles.  You're saving a reference to a temporary return?  Why?

> I think - using const type& var = function() still has a potential optimization benefit - which compiler may avoid the move of the return var from function to this scope.

Not at all.  As Matt said, RVO is the proper way here.  The compiler will construct the return direction into your variable without even using a move constructor.  What you've done is just undefined behavior.

Thanks.
I modified as you explained.
I submit a doc update - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/73994
It seems reasonable to me
